titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. My brother went in to Boston, and to Medford, to attempt a settlement with the Directors of the Canal. Mr: Townsend, with Mr: T. Greenleaf— Coll: Humphreys with Mr: Moses Young, and Mr: & Mrs: Storer were here successively on visits— In the afternoon Dr: & Mrs: Tufts and Mrs: Cranch with whom I went home. I found little time this day either for writing or reading— Bathed in the morning.

2. Bathed again at the wharf, and after breakfast went out with my brother, shooting on the Marshes; and over fatigued myself.— In the evening, went to tea at Mr: Quincy’s— Mr: & Mrs: Ford from S. Carolina, were there, & Mr: W. Crafts— We had music from the ladies.— Found myself quite unwell on going to bed.

3. Very unwell, all Night— Had some fever, and could get no sleep.— Pass’d the day idly— Wrote little, and read nothing worth reading— Miss N. Storer was here. In the evening I went up to Mr: Cranch’s, and carried a letter for my wife.

4. Had a pretty good Night, and am this day much better than yesterday— My Aunt Smith pass’d the day here. My brother dined with the club at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s.— I read part of Robertson’s History of Charles 5. and Mrs: Warren’s Ladies of Castille.
5. Heard Mr: Fiske of Cambridge— Mr: & Mrs: D. Greenleaf, Miss Ingraham and Miss Dawes were here this Evening— I read Butler’s 3 Sermons on Human Nature.

6. Inoculated a number of peach, plum, and pear-trees, and planted some stones— Wrote to Mr: R. Bird at New-York and to Mr Dunlap at Alexandria— Read the 7th: Iliad in Pope and Cowper.— In the Evening at Mr: Cranch’s— Company there at tea.

7. My brother went this morning to Randolph— The meeting of the Neponset Bridge Directors is postponed.— I wrote but little— In the afternoon went up to my farm and inoculated three of my peach-trees— Budded also several at my father’s.

8. Went to Cambridge, and attended a meeting of the Academy of Sciences— The notice given to the members of this meeting, had been short, and it was thinly attended. Several communications were received and read— Dined with President Willard— Judge Davis— Judge Atkinson of New-Hampshire with his family— & Mrs: Pickering with her Son (the late Judge Pickering’s wife & son) were there— I returned home early this Evening— Found Mrs: Cranch and Mrs: Wainwright at my Mother’s. I had not seen Mrs: Wainwright since the year 1789. And she had no recollection of having seen me since 1778.

9. Wrote letters this morning to the members newly elected of the Academy, and to the persons for whom votes of thanks have pass’d— Mr: T. Greenleaf, Mr: Black and Mr: Quincy were here this afternoon— I read some papers on the management and cultivation of trees— A subject to which I propose to give some attention.
10. Very warm— Went out with my brother on a shooting party, all the forenoon, but with very poor success. Read the 8th: book of Pope’s Iliad—

11. Went into Boston this morning, and attended a meeting of J. Ripley’s Commissioners, to decide upon a certain claim upon his Estate— Which was rejected— Received several letters— Return’d to Quincy to dinner, but arrived late. Mr: & Mrs: Smith, Mr: W. Sullivan, Mr: Quincy and their ladies with other company were here at dinner— In the evening, I called at Mr: D. Greenleaf’s, to deliver him a letter.
12. Heard Mr: Whitney.— Read Butler’s Sermon on the Government of the tongue, and the two upon Compassion— Wrote to Mrs: A— Mr: B. Adams was here in the Evening.

13. Walk’d up to Briesler’s this morning before breakfast. Went with my father down to his farm on the borders of Germantown, and over the hills, in search of young walnut trees— Found a number of them, as well as of hazle-nuts— In the afternoon read Montaigne on certain verses of Virgil, and Cowper’s 8th: Iliad— Mr: Otis and his family here this Night; on their return from Plymouth.

14. Mr: Otis and his family return’d to Boston— My brother went to Plymouth, with Mr: Bracket.— Attended at 10 this morning, a meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge, at Mr: Quincy’s— Only Mr: Black, Mr: Beale and Mr: Quincy there— Our business kept us untill 1.— My father received a letter from Judge Davis, respecting the attendance of the Academy at the funeral of Dr: Howard— This afternoon I read the 9th: Iliad in both translations. The Embassy to Achilles is interesting— But the great part of Phoenix’s speech perfectly tedious and unseasonable.

15. Went to Boston with my father— Met Mr: S. A. Otis on the Common; who engaged us to dine with him. I called at Judge Davis’s, to enquire of the arrangements made for the Academy.— Mrs: Lincoln and her son dined with us at Mr: Otis’s— At 3. we attended at the Academy’s room; found only Mr: Freeman there. We proceeded to the house of the deceased, and immediately after to the meeting-house— A prayer was made
by Dr: Lathrop, and a sermon delivered by President Willard, who was deeply affected with his subject. The funeral then went in procession to the burying ground at the North-end; and did not reach it, untill past 7. in the evening— Immediately after which we return’d to Quincy.

16. Mr: W. Cunningham, pass’d the day here— Mr: W. Channing was here this afternoon— I spent the Evening at Mr: Quincy’s— The Members of the Wednesday Evening Club were there.— I read Pope’s translation of the tenth Iliad; containing the nocturnal expedition of Diomed and Ulysses.

17. My Mother is quite unwell— I received from the Secretary of State a copy of the laws of the last Session of Congress— Mr: Cunningham left us— Miss H. Otis, and Eliza Smith here.— I read Cowper’s 10th: Iliad, and part of Du Marsais’ treatise on tropes— Went for Mrs: Cranch this afternoon—

18. My brother returned this morning from Plymouth; and with Mr: Shaw, dined at Captain Beale’s. I continued reading Du Marsais, and this afternoon read Pope’s 11th: Iliad— Containing the Acts of Agamemnon. The battles are so numerous in the Iliad, that they become tedious— And the long speech of Nestor to Patroclus at the close of this book is of the same character.

19. Heard Mr: S. Willard, the Librarian of Harvard University; who dined with us.— Read three Sermons of Butler, on the Character of Balaam, on Resentment, and on forgiveness of injuries— Wrote to my wife— My Mother continues very unwell— Mr: T. Greenleaf & Lady were here this Evening.
20. Great heat and drought— Went up to Mr: Cranch’s, this morning before breakfast— Met Mr: Briesler on my return— Bathed at Mr: Black’s wharf— Read Du Marsais— Cowper’s 11th: and Pope’s 12th: Iliad.
21. Finished reading the Treatise of Du Marsais on Tropes— In the afternoon went out with my brother on a shooting party— Company of ladies here to tea.— Miss Susan Storer here at dinner.

22. Mr: T. Greenleaf was here this morning, and invited me to dine with him to-morrow— Mr: Black, for the club on Saturday.— Mr: Harris of Dorchester was also here.— My Mother very unwell the whole day. I read the first Chapter of Aristotle’s Treatise on Rhetoric— And Cowper’s 12th: Iliad— In all the most shining passages of the original Pope if he does not exactly give the ideas of Homer, he never fails to give something that will serve the turn as well— The speeches of Hector to Polydamas, and of Sarpedon to Glaucus in this Book are distinguished instances, in which he has improved upon Homer.— In the evening I finished reading Kotzebue’s Crusaders.

23. Dined with my brother and Mr: Shaw, at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s— Dr: Warren and his family were there— And Mr: and Mrs: D. Greenleaf— In the evening we had a wedding at home— Mr: Richard Dexter was married to Miss Rebecca Tyrrell, by Mr: Whitney.— A numerous company attended the nuptials, and the Ball was continued late into the Night.— I began to analyze the laws of last Session of Congress this morning.

24. Employed on the U.S. Laws— And Aristotle’s Rhetoric in the forenoon— Pope and Cowper’s Iliad, Book 13 this afternoon. Walk’d up to my farm just before dinner— Found all the trees I inoculated have failed. Engaged in collecting and planting Stones.

25. Miss Harriet Otis and Miss Eliza Smith went home— My occupations are again becoming regular; with the Laws of the United States, Aristotle, and the two translations of Homer— Read the 14th: Iliad in both. My brother and Mr: Shaw dined with the club at Mr: Black’s.— I began also this day, in addition to the other books on which I am busied to read Cicero’s Treatise on Rhetorical Invention.

26. Heard Mr: Ware.— Read Butler’s 10th: Sermon— On Self-deceit; and 11th: and 12th: on the love of our neighbour.— This afternoon I walk’d with Mr: B. Adams over a young orchard set out by him about two years ago. Took tea there— In the evening, wrote to Mrs: A.

27. My brother and Mr: T. Greenleaf went this morning to Dedham, and thence return’d to dinner at Doctor Warren’s, on Jamaica plains— There Mr: Shaw and I met them— We visited Dr: Warren’s garden and nursery of trees, which is very considerable and flourishing.— Besides a great variety of peaches, nectarines, plums pears, nuts, and cherries he has the almond, and service trees— In his nursery there is a peach and plum-tree, growing in two branches from one natural Stock.— His son, with his wife, and Miss Mason, were there, and Coll: Welles came out from Boston at tea.— We return’d to Quincy somewhat late, and found Mrs: Allen, at my father’s; and I received at length two letters from my wife.

28. I went into Boston this morning with my brother. My object was to attend a meeting of the Historical Society, at 4 in the afternoon. I went into the Court-house, where the Supreme Court of the State is in Session. The cause between Boylston and Gill, which has engaged the Court nearly a week, was just at its close; and Judge Sewall was addressing the Jury.— I saw Mr: Babcock and Mr: Touro who desired me to attend on the trial of a couple of actions, which they expect will immediately come on.— Mr: H. Otis invited me to dine with him, which I did— But it prevented my attendance at the Society, for he had a large Company, and dined very late— We returned to Quincy in the Evening.— Received a letter from Mrs: Adams.

29. Commencement day.— I went out on a shooting party with my brother this morning; and he went out again with B. Adams in the afternoon— I did little but read the 15th: Book of Pope’s Iliad.— Mr: Peabody came from Cambridge this Evening, with a young man by the name of Gilman.

30. Went into Boston this morning, with Mr: Shaw, who returns to Stay— Attended at the Supreme Court, which was engaged in the trial of criminal Causes— Call’d on Mr Dexter— Dined with Mr: J. Gardner. Engaged to lease my house in Half-Court-Square, to a Mr: Delisle— Delivered him the key; and he is to take the house from the 1st: of September— Received a letter from Mrs: Adams— In the evening I returned alone to Quincy.

31. My Mother and Mrs: Allen went over to Weymouth— Very warm day— I read Cowper’s 15th: Iliad, and part of the 16th: in Pope— Bathed this morning at Mr: Black’s wharf.— Drew the lease of my house in Half-Court Square.
Day.— Irregular and indolent.
